discovery_rule.description: Discovery disks in /dev and add S.M.A.RT Itens , Triggers and Graphs

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [001] Raw_Read_Error_Rate
item_prototype.description: Indicates the rate of hardware read errors that occurred when reading data from a disk surface. A non-zero value indicates a problem with either the disk surface or read/write heads. Note that Seagate drives often report a raw value that is very high even on new drives, and does not thereby indicate a failure.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [002] Throughput_Performance
item_prototype.description: Overall (general) throughput performance of a hard disk drive. If the value of this attribute is decreasing there is a high probability that there is a problem with the disk.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [003] Spin_Up_Time
item_prototype.description: Average time of spindle spin up (from zero RPM to fully operational [millisecs]).

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [004] Start_Stop_Count
item_prototype.description: A tally of spindle start/stop cycles. The spindle turns on, and hence the count is increased, both when the hard disk is turned on after having before been turned entirely off (disconnected from power source) and when the hard disk returns from having previously been put to sleep mode.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [005] Reallocated_Sector_Ct
item_prototype.description: Count of reallocated sectors. When the hard drive finds a read/write/verification error, it marks this sector as "reallocated" and transfers data to a special reserved area (spare area). This process is also known as remapping, and "reallocated" sectors are called remaps. This is why, on modern hard disks, "bad blocks" cannot be found while testing the surface – all bad blocks are hidden in reallocated sectors. However, as the number of reallocated sectors increases, the read/write speed tends to decrease. The raw value normally represents a count of the number of bad sectors that have been found and remapped. Thus, the higher the attribute value, the more sectors the drive has had to reallocate.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [007] Seek_Error_Rate
item_prototype.description: Rate of seek errors of the magnetic heads. If there is a partial failure in the mechanical positioning system, then seek errors will arise. Such a failure may be due to numerous factors, such as damage to a servo, or thermal widening of the hard disk. More seek errors indicates a worsening condition of a disk’s surface or the mechanical subsystem, or both. Note that Seagate drives often report a raw value that is very high, even on new drives, and this does not normally indicate a failure.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [008] Seek_Time_Performance
item_prototype.description: Average performance of seek operations of the magnetic heads. If this attribute is decreasing, it is a sign of problems in the mechanical subsystem.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [009] Power_On_Hours
item_prototype.description: Count of hours in power-on state. The raw value of this attribute shows total count of hours (or minutes, or seconds, depending on manufacturer) in power-on state.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [010] Spin_Retry_Count
item_prototype.description: Average performance of seek operations of the magnetic heads. If this attribute is decreasing, it is a sign of problems in the mechanical subsystem.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [011] Calibration_Retry_Count
item_prototype.description: This attribute indicates the number of times recalibration was requested (under the condition that the first attempt was unsuccessful). An increase of this attribute value is a sign of problems in the hard disk mechanical subsystem.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [012] Power_Cycle_Count
item_prototype.description: This attribute indicates the count of full hard disk power on/off cycles.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [183] Runtime_Bad_Block
item_prototype.description: Western Digital, Samsung or Seagate attribute: Total number of data blocks with detected, uncorrectable errors encountered during normal operation

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [184] End-to-End_Error
item_prototype.description: This attribute is a part of HPs SMART IV technology and it means that after transferring through the cache RAM data buffer the parity data between the host and the hard drive did not match.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [187] Reported_Uncorrect
item_prototype.description: A number of errors that could not be recovered using hardware ECC (see attribute 195).

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [188] Command_Timeout
item_prototype.description: A number of aborted operations due to HDD timeout. Normally this attribute value should be equal to zero and if you have values far above zero, then most likely you have some serious problems with your power supply or you have an oxidized data cable.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [189] High_Fly_Writes
item_prototype.description: HDD producers implement a Fly Height Monitor that attempts to provide additional protections for write operations by detecting when a recording head is flying outside its normal operating range. If an unsafe fly height condition is encountered, the write process is stopped, and the information is rewritten or reallocated to a safe region of the hard drive. This attribute indicates the count of these errors detected over the lifetime of the drive. This feature is implemented in most modern Seagate drives and some of Western Digital’s drives, beginning with the WD Enterprise WDE18300 and WDE9180 Ultra2 SCSI hard drives, and will be included on all future WD Enterprise products.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [190] Airflow_Temperature_Cel
item_prototype.description: Airflow temperature on Western Digital HDs

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [191] G-Sense_Error_Rate
item_prototype.description: Frequency of mistakes as a result of impact loads

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [192] Power-Off_Retract_Count
item_prototype.description: Number of times the heads are loaded off the media. Heads can be unloaded without actually powering off. (or Emergency Retract Cycle count – Fujitsu)

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [193] Load_Cycle_Count
item_prototype.description: Count of load/unload cycles into head landing zone position. The typical lifetime rating for laptop (2.5-in) hard drives is 200,000 to 600,000 load cycles. Some laptop drives are programmed to unload the heads whenever there has not been any activity for about five seconds. Many Linux installations write to the filesystem a few times a minute in the background. As a result, there may be 100 or more load cycles per hour, and the load cycle rating may be exceeded in less than a year.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [194] Temperature_Celsius
item_prototype.description: Current internal temperature.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [195] Hardware_ECC_Recovered
item_prototype.description: Time between ECC-corrected errors or number of ECC on-the-fly errors. Sources differ on this point.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [196] Reallocated_Event_Count
item_prototype.description: Count of remap operations. The raw value of this attribute shows the total number of attempts to transfer data from reallocated sectors to a spare area. Both successful & unsuccessful attempts are counted.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [197] Current_Pending_Sector
item_prototype.description: Number of "unstable" sectors (waiting to be remapped). If the unstable sector is subsequently written or read successfully, this value is decreased and the sector is not remapped. Read errors on the sector will not remap the sector, it will only be remapped on a failed write attempt.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [198] Offline_Uncorrectable
item_prototype.description: The total number of uncorrectable errors when reading/writing a sector. A rise in the value of this attribute indicates defects of the disk surface and/or problems in the mechanical subsystem. (or Off-Line Scan Uncorrectable Sector Count – Fujitsu)

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [199] UDMA_CRC_Error_Count
item_prototype.description: The number of errors in data transfer via the interface cable as determined by ICRC (Interface Cyclic Redundancy Check).

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [200] Multi_Zone_Error_Rate
item_prototype.description: The total number of errors when writing a sector.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [240] Head_Flying_Hours
item_prototype.description: Time while head is positioning

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [241] Total_LBAs_Written
item_prototype.description: Total count of LBAs written

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} ATTRIBUTES - [242] Total_LBAs_Read
item_prototype.description: Total count of LBAs read. Some S.M.A.R.T. utilities will report a negative number for the raw value since in reality it has 48 bits rather than 32

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME} OVERALL HEALTH Self-Assessment Test
item_prototype.description: If test result is NOT PASSED, then that means the SMART firmware believes that the drive is in imminent danger of catastrophic failure, so it is imperative to copy off ALL important data. Usually, it is best to copy off the most important files, then the next most important files, then the next, and so on, because the drive may completely quit before you finish copying.

trigger_prototype.name: Disk problem (Disk has been canged) on {#DISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Disk has been changed in the host

trigger_prototype.name: Disk problem ([005] Reallocated Sectors) on {#DISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Count of reallocated sectors. When the hard drive finds a read/write/verification error, it marks that sector as "reallocated" and transfers data to a special reserved area (spare area). This process is also known as remapping, and reallocated sectors are called "remaps". The raw value normally represents a count of the bad sectors that have been found and remapped. Thus, the higher the attribute value, the more sectors the drive has had to reallocate. This allows a drive with bad sectors to continue operation; however, a drive which has had any reallocations at all is significantly more likely to fail in the near future.[3] While primarily used as a metric of the life expectancy of the drive, this number also affects performance. As the count of reallocated sectors increases, the read/write speed tends to become worse because the drive head is forced to seek to the reserved area whenever a remap is accessed. If sequential access speed is critical, the remapped sectors can be manually marked as bad blocks in the file system in order to prevent their use.

trigger_prototype.name: Disk problem ([010] Spin Retry) on {#DISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Count of retry of spin start attempts. This attribute stores a total count of the spin start attempts to reach the fully operational speed (under the condition that the first attempt was unsuccessful). An increase of this attribute value is a sign of problems in the hard disk mechanical subsystem.

trigger_prototype.name: Disk problem ([184] End-to-End Error) on {#DISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: This attribute is a part of Hewlett-Packard's SMART IV technology, as well as part of other vendors' IO Error Detection and Correction schemas, and it contains a count of parity errors which occur in the data path to the media via the drive's cache RAM.

trigger_prototype.name: Disk problem ([188] Command Timeout) on {#DISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: The count of aborted operations due to HDD timeout. Normally this attribute value should be equal to zero and if the value is far above zero, then most likely there will be some serious problems with power supply or an oxidized data cable.

trigger_prototype.name: Disk problem ([196] Reallocated Event Count) on {#DISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Count of remap operations. The raw value of this attribute shows the total count of attempts to transfer data from reallocated sectors to a spare area. Both successful & unsuccessful attempts are counted.

trigger_prototype.name: Disk problem ([197] Current Pending Sector) on {#DISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Count of "unstable" sectors (waiting to be remapped, because of unrecoverable read errors). If an unstable sector is subsequently read successfully, the sector is remapped and this value is decreased. Read errors on a sector will not remap the sector immediately (since the correct value cannot be read and so the value to remap is not known, and also it might become readable later); instead, the drive firmware remembers that the sector needs to be remapped, and will remap it the next time it's written. However some drives will not immediately remap such sectors when written; instead the drive will first attempt to write to the problem sector and if the write operation is successful then the sector will be marked good (in this case, the "Reallocation Event Count" (0xC4) will not be increased). This is a serious shortcoming, for if such a drive contains marginal sectors that consistently fail only after some time has passed following a successful write operation, then the drive will never remap these problem sectors.

trigger_prototype.name: Disk problem ([198] Offline Uncorrectable) on {#DISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: The total count of uncorrectable errors when reading/writing a sector. A rise in the value of this attribute indicates defects of the disk surface and/or problems in the mechanical subsystem.

trigger_prototype.name: OVERALL HEALTH Self-Assessment Test on {#DISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: If test result is FAILED, then that means the SMART firmware believes that the drive is in imminent danger of catastrophic failure, so it is imperative to copy off ALL important data. Usually, it is best to copy off the most important files, then the next most important files, then the next, and so on, because the drive may completely quit before you finish copying.

trigger_prototype.name: UDMA disk errors on {#DISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: The count of errors in data transfer via the interface cable as determined by ICRC (Interface Cyclic Redundancy Check).
